facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 744 of 1966 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 744 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 25, 1965 of the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal, Bom-

facts.text: Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal delivered judgment and order dated February 25, 1965 in Revenue Appeal No. 40 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: bay in No. Rev. A. 40 of 1962. T. Desai and Naunit Lal, for the appellant. L. Sanghi and S. P. Nayar, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was deliv

facts.text: Special Deputy Collector, Khoti, Kolaba awarded Rs. 837.94 as compensation to appellants for their 0-12-1 1/3 share in village Kotheri under s. 12 of Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal, Bombay in Revenue Appeal No. 40 of 1962 whereby the Tribunal set aside the award of the Special Deputy Collector,  Khoti , Kolaba under s. 12 of the Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949 directing the amount of Rs. 837.94 to be paid to the appellants for their share of Rs. 0-12-1 1/3 share in village Kotheri, Taluka Mahal, District Kolaba and remanded the case for retrial stating the points for decision by the Special Deputy Collector.

facts.text: Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal set aside the award and remanded the case to Special Deputy Collector for retrial.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the Tribunal set aside the award of the Special Deputy Collector,  Khoti , Kolaba under s. 12 of the Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949 directing the amount of Rs. 837.94 to be paid to the appellants for their share of Rs. 0-12-1 1/3 share in village Kotheri, Taluka Mahal, District Kolaba and remanded the case for retrial stating the points for decision by the Special Deputy Collector.

facts.text: Appellants made application to Collector of Kolaba on October 9, 1950 for compensation for Khoti rights in reserved forest and unassessed lands under Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On October 9, 1950 the appellants made an application before the Collector of Kolaba for obtaining companypensation for Khoti rights in respect of reserved forest and unassessed lands in accordance with the provisions of the Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949  Act No. VI of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Village Kotheri in Taluka Mahal, District Kolaba is a Khoti village of Pat leasehold.

anchor.surface_text: In the application, the appellants stated that the village Kotheri in Taluka Mahal was a Khoti village of Pat  leasehold  and that the appellants had a Khoti share of Rs. 0- 12-1 1/2 in the village.

facts.text: Appellants claimed total compensation of Rs. 17,615 for entire village, their share Rs. 13,333-9-0.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants said that the total companypensation which they claimed for the entire village came to Rs. 17,615/- and that the share of Rs. 0-12-1 1/3 came to Rs. 13,333-9-0.

facts.text: Appellants claimed Rs. 7,480 for loss under reserved forest of 74 acres 32 gunthas.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further claimed a sum of Rs. 7,480/- in respect of loss under the reserved forest  74 acres 32 gunthas , and a sum of Rs. 6,850/- being the one- third share of the price at the present market rate of the trees etc., that at present stand in the reserved forest.

facts.text: Appellants claimed Rs. 6,850 as one-third share of market price of trees in reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: and a sum of Rs. 6,850/- being the one- third share of the price at the present market rate of the trees etc., that at present stand in the reserved forest.

facts.text: Appellants filed preliminary statement before Special Deputy Collector, Kolaba on January 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1962 the appellants filed before the Special Deputy Collector, Kolaba a preliminary statement.

facts.text: Appellants contended that Khots guarded forest in proprietary rights around 1860 A.D. and land was taken as reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: In that statement the appellants companytended that the Khots used to guard the forest in their proprietary rights in about the year 1860 A.D. and that the said land had been taken to the reserved forest.

facts.text: Appellants contended they had partnership with State in forest income, not abolished by Khoti Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further companytended that they had a partnership with the State in respect of forest income, that is, in the division of agricultural produce and that the partnership in the forest income has number been abo- lished under the Khoti Abolition Act and the partnership is still subsisting.

facts.text: Special Deputy Collector, Khoti, Kolaba made award on May 15, 1962 granting Rs. 837-94 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1962 the Special Deputy Collector  Khoti  Kolaba made his award granting a sum of Rs. 837-94 as companypensation.

facts.text: Appellants filed appeal to Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal in Revenue Appeal No. REV. A. 40 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the award the appellants preferred an appeal before the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal being Revenue Appeal No. REV. A. 40 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellants submitted written arguments to Tribunal on September 16, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, 1963 the appellants submitted before the Tribunal their written arguments.

facts.text: Appellants filed supplementary arguments to Tribunal on September 18, 1964, November 21, 1964, and February 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On September 18, 1964, November 21, 1964 and February 1, 1965 the appellants filed before the Tribunal further supplementary arguments in writing.

facts.text: Tribunal held that Khoti in Kolaba has no rights in village or reserved forest without separate sanad or grant.

anchor.surface_text: On February 21, 1965 the Tribunal delivered its judgment holding that the Khoti in the Kolaba cannot tary rights in the village or in the reserved forest unless he proves that he has separate sanad or grant companyveying to him these proprietary rights.

facts.text: Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949 came into force on April 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949 came into force with effect from April 12, 1959.

facts.text: Reserved forest attached to village Kotheri is 74 acres 32 gunthas.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further claimed a sum of Rs. 7,480/- in respect of loss under the reserved forest  74 acres 32 gunthas ,

facts.text: Appellants claim proprietary rights in survey plots 130 and 132 of Mauza Kotheri.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel said that the appellant should be given sufficient opportunity of proving by oral and documentary evidence that they had proprietary rights in survey plots 130 and 132 of Mau a Kotheri in the status of kothi.

facts.text: Sud of 1869 at p. 124-A is an important document for appellants' claim.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended on behalf of the appellants that the Sud of 1869 at p. 124-A of the paper book was an important document id the Tribunal has number companyrectly appreciated the meaning of the  1  26 Bom. L.R. 754. words Khalsa and Varkas.

facts.text: Maharashtra Act 43 of 1963 amended the Act to provide compensation for loss of share in forest revenue, effective October 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was amended by the Maharashtra Act 43 of 1963 by which payment of companypensation was provided to any loss of share in the forest revenue and the Amending Act came into force on October 6, 1963 and it was provided that the claim for companypensation can be entertained upto March 31, 1964.

facts.text: Tribunal remanded case for decision on whether appellants are proprietors of lands in Kotheri or reserved forest.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal has remanded the case for retrial to the Special Deputy Collector, Kolaba for decision on the following points Whether the appellants prove that they are the proprietors of the lands in the village of Kotheri or in the lands attached as a reserved forest to the said village

facts.text: Supreme Court affirms Tribunal's remand order dated February 25, 1965 and dismisses appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to these observations we affirm the order of the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal dated February 25, 1965 and dismiss the appeal. There will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act provides for the abolition of the Khoti tenure and states With effect from and on the date on which this Act comes into force,- (1) the Khoti tenure shall, wherever it prevails in the districts of Ratnagiri and Kolaba, be deemed to have been abolished and (2) save as expressly provided by this Act, all the incidents of the said tenure shall be deemed to have been extinguished, notwithstanding any law, custom, or usage or anything contained in any sanad, grant, kabulayat, lease, decree or order of any court or any other instrument.

concepts.interpretation: Abolishes Khoti tenure and extinguishes its incidents.

The legal position is well-established that khotis in the district of Kolaba are hereditary farmers of land revenue and are entitled to hold villages as khoti on their entering every year into the customary- kabulayat. According to Molesworths Dictionary khot means a renter of a village, a farmer of land or revenue, a farmer of the customs, a contractor or monopolist an hereditary officer whose duty it is to collect the revenue of the village for Government, also an officer appointed for this office a tribe of Brahmins in the Southern Konkan.

concepts.interpretation: Khots in Kolaba have no proprietary right in soil, only hereditary right to farm revenue via annual kabulayat.

arguments.claim: Khotis in Kolaba district are hereditary farmers of land revenue with no proprietary right in soil but entitled to hold villages on annual kabulayat

anchor.surface_text: The legal position is well-established that khotis in the district of Kolaba are hereditary farmers of land revenue and are entitled to hold villages as khoti on their entering every year into the customary- kabulayat. According to Molesworths Dictionary khot means a renter of a village, a farmer of land or revenue, a farmer of the customs, a contractor or monopolist an hereditary officer whose duty it is to collect the revenue of the village for Government, also an officer appointed for this office a tribe of Brahmins in the Southern Konkan.

arguments.claim: In absence of sanad deed or grant no proprietary rights over reserved forest or uncultivated land for Khoti

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that in the absence of a sanad or a deed or a grant granting proprietary rights over the soil a Khoti is not the proprietor of the lands constituted as reserved forest in the khoti village and is not entitled to any proprietary right in the uncultivated or forest land.

arguments.claim: Right to trees vests in Government under Section 41 Land Revenue Code unless property of individuals

anchor.surface_text: Section 41 of the Land Revenue Code declares that the right to all trees, bushwood, jungle or other natural product, wherever growing, except in so far as the same may be the property of individuals capable of holding property, vests in Government.

arguments.claim: Forest tracts and old waste presumed to belong to Government unless displaced by positive evidence of grant or allowance of adverse rights

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary in this context to refer to the presumption that forest tracts and old waste belong to Government unless the presumption is displaced by positive evidence that Government has granted rights in any particular tract or piece of land or has consciously allowed adverse rights to grow therein.

arguments.claim: If khot is proprietor of soil then proprietor of trees by quicquid plantatur solo solo cedit

anchor.surface_text: In such a case the principle is quicquid plantatur solo solo cedit.

arguments.claim: To claim under Dunlops Proclamation must prove land in permanent occupation in own right

anchor.surface_text: It was held by Shah, J., that the Dunlops Proclamation could apply to Varkas lands in a khoti village but if any person claimed the benefit of the Proclamation he should prove that the land, on which the trees stood, was his in a popular sense, that is, it was sufficiently marked out as being in his permanent occupation in his own right so as to make it properly describable as his land.

holdings.text: We affirm the above order of remand and further direct that an opportunity should be given by the Special Deputy Collector to both sides to adduce such evidence as they choose on these points. After taking such evidence the Special Deputy Collector will pronounce the award in the light of the law laid down in this judgment.

holdings.text: Subject to these observations we affirm the order of the Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal dated February 25, 1965 and dismiss the appeal. There will be no order as to costs.

precedents.citation: Tajubai v. Sub-Collector of Kulaba 1 5 Bom. High Court Reports 132

anchor.surface_text: In Tajubai v. Sub-Collector of Kulaba 1  it was held by the majority of the Full Bench that the khotis have number proprietary right in the soil of their village but only hereditary right to farm the  1  5 Bom. High Court Reports 132.

precedents.cited_proposition: khotis have no proprietary right in the soil of their village but only hereditary right to farm the revenue and that if the khots right is the hereditary farming of the revenue, the living principle of that right would not be property inherent in the khot, but a perpetually running contract with the State

precedents.citation: Ganpati Gopal Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India 1 26 Bom. L.R. 754

anchor.surface_text: In Ganpati Gopal Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India 1  the Bombay High Court reiterated that khots in the district of Kolaba are hereditary farmers of the revenue and are entitled to hold their villages as Khoti on their entering every year into the customary Kabulayats. At p. 768 Macleod C.J. stated The relationship between the Khot and the Government, to my mind, is perfectly clear.

precedents.case_name: Ganpati Gopal Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: khots in the district of Kolaba are hereditary farmers of the revenue and are entitled to hold their villages as Khoti on their entering every year into the customary Kabulayats; relationship between Khot and Government is that Khot is an occupant securing revenue payment, with village lands in three classes: Dharekari, Khotnisbat, Khoti Khasgi

precedents.citation: Kodoth Ambu Nair v. Secretary of State for India 1 51 I.A. 257

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary in this context to refer to the presumption that forest tracts and old waste belong to Government unless the presumption is displaced by positive evidence that Government has granted rights in any particular tract or piece of land or has consciously allowed adverse rights to grow therein.  see Kodoth Ambu Nair v. Secretary of State for India.  1  51 I.A. 257.

precedents.case_name: Kodoth Ambu Nair v. Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption that forest tracts and old waste belong to Government unless the presumption is displaced by positive evidence that Government has granted rights in any particular tract or piece of land or has consciously allowed adverse rights to grow therein

precedents.citation: Sadashiv Parshram Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India 2 20 Bom. L.R. 141

anchor.surface_text: In Sadashiv Parshram Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India  2   the question arose whether the khots were entitled to  1  51 I.A. 257.  2  20 Bom. L.R. 141. recover the sale proceeds of certain teak trees sold by Government grown on Varkas lands. In the alternative the khots claimed one-third share of the sale proceeds relying upon the clause in the kabulayat.

precedents.case_name: Sadashiv Parshram Risbud v. The Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: khots not entitled to full sale proceeds of teak trees on Varkas lands but only one-third share as per kabulayat; no claim under s. 40 of Land Revenue Code or Dunlops Proclamation unless land proven to be in permanent occupation as his own
precedents.cited_holding: as between the khots and the Government the matter in dispute was concluded by the kabulayat and the khot could not obtain more than one-third of the proceeds of the sale of the trees; Dunlops Proclamation could apply to Varkas lands but claimant must prove land was his in popular sense

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
